ï»¿Execution Version Dated tC L(a^k, 2015 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global In rastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is e itered into on 2015 between: (1) SUMITOMO MITSUI BANK NG CORPORATION, headquartered at 1-1-2, Marunouchi, C1 i) ol a- ku, Tokyo, Japan, ("SMBC") and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPM Of ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), heaJquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, US, e INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvan : Avenue, NW, Washington, I C 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("1IlGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington. DC 20 33, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and togethel, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad internation I recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Intern i ial Organizations (IOs), the G7', and the private sector represented by the B20 that investin in-le infrastructure of Emerging Plarkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to n x:: id access to basic services an J raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic .110 th targets. (B) Meeting this need present; a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on E (s: ig sources of infrastructure finince-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coort in ad effort is needed to mobilize rivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of rob ist pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects and t li: is understood to be the greatef t barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investme r . (D) Governments, development :inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an int( i in developing the market for p ivate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand , i( E in the numbers of structurally s )und and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual eme g ;e of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range of :iii te investors that actively participate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will :ii!r fit from collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowleI,]c to find solutions to complex nfrastructure financing challenges that no single institution ix Id achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, tho Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure la ci ty Partnership Program ("GIF"]. The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leveragi I ie efforts of the wide range of institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructu ' is th the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prepE,"It, n, structuring, and risk mitigatiDn for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, tt ,= IF aims to complement existin ) and proposed services and initiatives currently supported :- ie Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepar w II- structured, infrastructure projects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for accessi II le expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from prosIe c: le private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater le 1'n: le of official resources in the ft ce of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular fo ai le and complex projects with th B potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now intere.ted in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure la ci ty Partnership Program, togeth )r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have corr e to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facil ty Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended to be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set OL n1 Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fc undational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collab:ii a:n, they are of an indicative nati re and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and / th other potential partners until the GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje t : 3 and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fi irther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing th) C F, with a view to formally estab ishing the program by June 2015. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the fore!loing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue to collaborate in developing thE GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the oles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categorj b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies applicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to projel t selection criteria anc coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includii 1 sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through thE Is of knowledge platfor ns for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali.:ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bank. is ad in Annex 2 will be invited o participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF de i :ir is finalized, additional collabo-ative efforts are required to develop the operational details c* ie GIF, at all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the ! ta 3d knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the 1i e of coordination between the P arties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration A rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment iy t Parties to enter into or provice support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisi )ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their common understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose an e; 31 obligations or liabilities on any Party. 3.2 This Collaboration A rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year from Ii i date thereof, unless superse led at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabora iN le activities contemplated herei i will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult with : -c: i 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manne - and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's support regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arrangement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatio':l other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of thE Parties under their constitue it documents, international conventions and any applicable lay s In witness whereof, each of the Paities has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executei n two (2) counterparts of equal conten- and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party as cf 1 le date first set forth above. 4
ï»¿Execution Version SUMITOMO MITSUI BANKING CORPORATION By: Fumiaki Kurahara Senior Managing Director 5
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO Al D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIOAL DEVELOP NT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATE INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: Bertrand Badre Managing Director and WE G Chief Fi a ial Officer 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preli minary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pr :j: s in emerging markets and de feloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatic n1 provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial : -ic institutional investor engagenent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex put lic-private partnerships and projects with potential for commern i, I viability which require projec preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastruc 1A r financing solutions that no siigle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coordi it >n resources in collaboration with the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of the 3i: - range of donor and developr ient finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructure, with the input 3nd ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemen cc Id stretch from upstream suppc rt on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to dow istream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhanceme it. 1.3 Over the longer terrr, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurec infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long- )r assets in faster growing economies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profiles 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to c perate according to the following core principles, to be finalize( I p )n agreement among GIF partn 3rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities th, t wI draw together cc mparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly those infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to be ; practice standan Is for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tec n il al and financial res)urces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, multi a:e al development ins:itutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and fl )xible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greater leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the reso irces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in th( development and implementition of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF par n are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partnt rs-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wil te considered Funding Partners. (ii) Technical Partners-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde( activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppo t instruments. (iii) Advisory Partn rs-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovoreign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as we : other multilatera or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure projects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparat:> i, optimal approac ies to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inve 3tment. 3.2 A GIF Governing C 3uncil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programming, management and use of fun,is, and development of operational policies and procedures; ai c hold the GIF Management Unit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, with advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compos li:i of the Governing Council will bo agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propo -c o comprise representatives of -unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dire it:i and Chief Financial Officer o: the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilit, t! coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve s E sounding board, providing guidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular witl ,: view to ensuring suitability o projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be adm nistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicated : ai i established for this purpose the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit widl fur:: cn I as a coordinating body as pr)jects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then move toward technical support anc financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead indi ,i:1 al projects. 4.2 GIF activity implemeltation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partner institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmen s according to specific project equirements and the project origination processes. Compositi:> f the implementation teams m 3y vary according to the need of individual projects and goverr n E ts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection ct iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the followi -1 principles: (i) Development Iripact-projects that support the development goals of the GIF partner institutions; (ii) Alignment-prc ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities a iI strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr :jects that require multiple parties to come together to provide structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a ble < financial instrum ants; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial, i;t ity, leverage public :unds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- ic as through Publ c-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's service delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrast[ucture investments that have global public good characteristic ;, si ch as climate friendly-projec s that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provision a infrastructure services; and trade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnec:i i and trade. 5.2 The scope of supp )rt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with I .i w to complementing the resou ces and support already available from partner entities and otl e, funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac V tI s, corresponding to major proje ct development stages: (i) Project definitior and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scre :' g; and legal, regulitory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparat on and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and FPP structuring; (iii) Transaction sup )ort and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, an J design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrang ng and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financir g packages from range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- including in particular the management of environmental and s:)::i: impacts and risks, and trans arency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastru:1 projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supportell operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements ft r external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an a proach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards and :) hi r standards and policies, and levelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GIF Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities. 9
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 2 Mult lateral Development Banks (MDBs) and their Respective Project Preparation Resources and Initiatives During the process of finalizing the design of the GIF, the following MDBs will be invited to particir ;3 E as initial Technical Partners. The oper)tional details for the GIF will at all times complement the E s' Ig efforts and facilities of these MDE s, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure 10 ct preparation resources and initiatives listed below: a. African DevelopmE nt Bank (AfDB) - NEPAD Infrastructure Project Preparation Ic ity (NEPAD-IPPF) as %tell as the project development business segment of Africa! C id various support effor ts for Africa-focused PPFs; b. Asian Development Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its pr( p:); d Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated n iric ial PPFs; c. European Bank fc r Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Tra -;i. n Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('IF F F d. European Investmf nt Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facilit'; f. Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure Tel 1 II al Assistance Facility (4FFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Corpra )n (IFC); and g. World Bank Groul (WBG) comprising the International Bank for Reconstructil n id Development (IBRD , the International Development Association (IDA), the Intern ilic al Finance Corporation (IFC), and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIG 6). 10
